en.name: Pink Cedar, Shingle Tree, Indian Ash
R104
en.description: 'R104' (A. cruentus) is a selection by Rodale Institute from a Mexican landrace . The plant is a tall annual up to 2 m, that produces full tassels of seed. Plants may need support when grain heads become heavy near maturation.

en.name: Burgundy
en.description: 'Burgundy' grain amaranth (A. hypochondriacus) is a tall, annual plant to 2 m in height that produces dark red seed heads which produce abundant white edible seeds. Ornamental leaves also add color. Mature plants may need staking to support the weight of the seed heads.

en.name: Manna
en.description: ‘Manna’ grain amaranth (A. hypochondriacus) is a tall, annual plant to 2 m in height that produces full, red-yellow tassels of seed. Mature plants may need staking to support the weight of the seed heads.

en.name: R103
en.description: ‘R 103’ grain amaranth (A. hypochondriacus) is a tall, annual plant to 2 m in height that produces full, red-yellow tassels of seed. This variety was selected by Rodale Institute from a Mexican landrace. Mature plants may need staking to support the weight of the seed heads.

en.name: RRP 1526B
en.description: ‘RRP 1526B’’ grain amaranth (A. hypochondriacus) is a variety from Kenya that is a tall, annual plant to 2 m in height that produces large, pink, full tassels of seed.. Mature plants may need staking to support the weight of the seed heads.

en.name: Agroforestry Select
en.description: ‘Agroforestry Select’ is a pigeon pea variety selected for use as an animal fodder. It can grow up to 3 m in height but does not bear a heavy crop of pods and seeds. This variety is also useful for intercropping and as a green manure.

en.name: Georgia TWO
en.description: 'Georgia TWO' pigeon pea was developed by Dr. Sharad Phatak at the University of Georgia. It is a short-duration, day-neutral variety and is said to be determinate. This variety is very vigorous and productive and may produce up to 4,480 kg of dry seed per hectare.

en.name: ICPL 8151
en.description: 'ICPL 8151' pigeon pea originates from part of a germplasm collection at ICRISAT in India. It is a long season, indeterminate variety, with creamy, white-colored seeds, growing up to 2 m in height, and taking 235 days to maturity.

en.name: Improved Red Maradol
en.description: 'Red Maradol' is an open pollinated variety that produces fruit when very young and short. Fruits are firm and keep well. This improved variety was selected for productivity and deep red flesh. ‘Red Maradol’ may produce fruit in as little as 7 months after planting.

en.name: Known You No. 1
en.description: ‘Known-You’ is a hybrid variety from Taiwan which has very large fruits, up to 3 kg, with yellow flesh.

en.name: Red Lady #786 F1
en.description: 'Red Lady #786 F1' is a hybrid variety from Taiwan with fruit up to 2 kg. It is a compact, shorter plant with firm, delicious red flesh.

en.name: Sunrise Solo
en.description: ‘Sunrise Solo’ is an open pollinated variety with small, reddish pink fruit averaging about 570 grams, which is sweet with a mild flavor.

en.name: Sunset Solo
en.description: ‘Sunset Solo’ is an open pollinated variety with sweet, red flesh. This cultivar comes from the same genetic parents as ‘Sunrise’. It was originally developed for the smaller sized fruits averaging about 450 grams.

en.name: Tainung No. 1
en.description: ‘Tainung No. 1’ is a hybrid variety from Taiwan, taller and more productive than ‘Red Lady’ with 1.1 kg fruits that are delicious but not quite as sweet as 'Red Lady'. The trees can have male, female, or bisexual flowers.

en.name: Waimanalo Solo
en.description: ‘Waimanalo Solo’ is an open pollinated variety with sweet, yellow flesh. Fruits vary in size with an average of 680 grams. A very high yielding variety, with strong disease and insect resistance.

en.planting_instructions: Plant 2 cm deep, 35 cm apart in 65 cm rows. Harvest regularly to encourage production, starting at 55 days.
en.name: Burgundy
en.description: 'Burgundy' grows to 1.5 m tall with green leaves and burgundy stems, branches, leaf ribs, and red-burgundy pods 15-20cm in length.

en.planting_instructions: Plant 2 cm deep, 35 cm apart in 65 cm rows. Harvest regularly to encourage production, starting at 52 days.
en.name: Clemson Spineless 80
en.description: ‘Clemson Spineless’ is a prolific producer of green spineless pods which can be harvested continuously for weeks. Plant reaches 1.5 m and pods are best at 5-8 cm.

en.planting_instructions: Plant 2 cm deep, 35 cm apart in 65 cm rows. Harvest regularly to encourage production.
en.name: Borneo
en.description: 'Borneo' - This variety produces extra long edible pods that can be up to 45cm long.

en.planting_instructions: Plant 2 cm deep, 35 cm apart in 65 cm rows. Harvest regularly to encourage production, starting at 55 days.
en.name: Prelude
en.description: ‘Prelude’ is a compact variety with lance-shaped leaves that allow easier harvest and let sunlight pass through the canopy and reach more of the lower leaves.

en.planting_instructions: Plant 2 cm deep, 35 cm apart in 75 cm rows. Harvest regularly to encourage production.
en.name: Pusa Makmahli
en.description: ‘Pusa Makmahli’ is a quick maturing okra from Northern India with light green pods. Plants can grow up to 3 m tall.

en.name: Red Creole
en.description: ‘Red Creole’ is a short day onion with red flesh, tough outer scales, and flattened globe shaped bulbs.

en.name: Red Burgundy
en.description: ‘Red Burgundy’ is a short day onion with smooth, glossy, purplish red skin and white flesh.

en.name: Ringmaster
en.description: ‘Ringmaster’ is a long day onion with large, white globe shaped bulbs.

en.name: White Sweet Spanish
en.description: ‘White Sweet Spanish’ is an intermediate day onion with a large white globe shaped bulb and firm flesh.

en.name: Greenleaf R108
en.description: This edible leaf amaranth (A. tricolor) from Taiwan has green leaves.

en.name: Merah
en.description: This edible leaf amaranth (A. tricolor) has green leaves with red stripes.

en.name: Tigerleaf R135
en.description: This edible leaf amaranth (A. tricolor) from Rodale has green leaves with red stripes. ‘Tigerleaf was the best performing vegetable amaranth in an ECHO observation trial in Florida.

en.name: Bouquet
en.description: 'Bouquet' was selected for its size and large yellow flowers. It is an early maturing variety growing to 60 cm in height.

en.name: Green
en.description: A medium to tall tree that produces sweet, creamy fruits. Fruits are green when mature.

en.name: Red
en.description: This 'Red' variety produces fruit with a reddish blush on medium to tall trees.

en.name: Atemoya
en.description: Atemoyas produce delicious-tasting fruits that resemble the cherimoya in flavor. The fragrant, snow white flesh is both sweet and subacid at the same time.

en.name: Soursop
en.description: Soursop is a tropical, low branching and shrubby tree to 10 m in height. Typically soursop fruit is processed into various drinks.

en.name: ICG 9257
en.description: ‘ICG 9257’ has a spreading growth habit with two peanuts per pod. In trials at ECHO this variety exhibited some resistant to foliar diseases.

en.name: Starfruit
en.description: Starfruit trees from seed will be variable in fruit color and flavor. It is suggested to seek local sources for grafting material so that trees will consistently produce fruit with desirable qualities.

en.name: Bangladesh
en.description: ‘Bangladesh’ (B. alba) is a large-leafed, vigourous, heat tolerant variety. It produces long, thick vines that do well sprawling on the ground, over other plants, or trained to trellises.

en.name: Green Vines
en.description: ‘Green Vines’ (B. alba) is a green-stemmed, climbing variety that thrives in hot, moist conditions.

en.name: Red
en.description: ‘Red’ (B. rubra) has red tinged leaves, stems, and flowers. This variety can also be used for dye and jelly.

en.name: Green and Red Mix
en.description: A mix of both a green-stemmed variety, 'Green Vines' (B. alba) and a red-stemmed variety, ‘Red’ (B. rubra).

en.name: Wax Gourd
en.description: This is the generic variety of Wax Gourd or Wintermelon.

en.name: Large Fruited
en.description: 'Large Fruited' is a variety of wax gourd that was selected for plants that produce especially large fruits.

en.name: Detroit Dark Red
en.description: 'Detroit Dark Red' is an open pollinated, versatile, midsized, heirloom beet for eating fresh or canning.

en.name: Florida Broadleaf
en.description: 'Florida Broadleaf' is an open pollinated, vigorous, mustard, well adapted to various conditions. It produces large and broad leaves, which are eaten cooked, and have potential for processing and marketing.

en.name: Suehlihung No. 2
en.description: 'Suehligung No 2' variety has lobed green leaves, can withstand both cold and heat, is slow to bolt, and can be harvested as early as 20 days after transplanting.

en.name: Danish Ballhead
en.description: 'Danish Ballhead' is an open-pollinated cabbage that produces extra-solid, heavy, round, heads 15 to 30cm in diameter, with light green flesh, and weighing up to 4.5 kg.

en.name: Waltham 29
en.description: 'Waltham 29' is an open-pollinated, heirloom, broccoli developed at the University of Massachusetts in the 1950s. The plants produce uniform, large heads, with consistent color.

en.name: Champion
en.description: ‘Champion’ is an improved Vates selection. It has dark green, large, cabbage-like leaves, that retain their eating quality up to 2 weeks longer than other Vates types.

en.name: Georgia Southern
en.description: ‘Georgia Southern’ is a popular, heirloom, southern US variety, that withstands both heat and cold. This variety is slow to bolt and does not form heads.

en.name: Vates
en.description: ‘Vates’ is a shorter variety than other collards, very productive, slow to bolt, and with good heat and frost tolerance.

en.name: Morris Heading
en.description: ‘Morris Heading’ is an open-pollinated, heirloom variety, that forms loose heads of broad, blue-green leaves. It is slow to bolt and is tolerant of both heat and cold.

en.name: Vates Blue Curled
en.description: 'Vates Blue Curled' is an open-pollinated kale variety bred for its blue, waxy, crumpled leaves.

en.name: Chinese
en.description: ‘Chinese’ Bok Choy is a nutritious, fast growing, green leafy vegetable, with large, glossy green leaves, and broad white stalks.

en.name: Tyfon Stubble
en.description: ‘Tyfon Stubble’ is a hybrid cross between Chinese Cabbage and Stubble Turnips, is a fast-growing, very leafy crop, and is mainly grown for forage.

en.name: Purple Top White Globe
en.description: 'Purple Top White Globe' turnips are open-pollinated, medium sized, crisp turnips, eaten fresh or cooked. Roots are best when the turnips are small, and the tops are eaten as greens.

en.name: Seven Top
en.description: 'Seven Top' is an open-pollinated variety that is grown almost exclusively for greens. The leaves are harvested when medium dark. The roots are tough, woody, and almost inedible.

en.name: Jalape√±o M
en.description: ‘Jalapeño M’ is an open pollinated hot pepper.  Fruit can reach 8 cm in length and 4 cm in diameter, are dark green to red and pungent (hot) with thick walls. (Scoville rating of 3500-6000).

en.name: Capistrano
en.description: 'Capistrano' is an open-pollinated, sweet, bell pepper that takes about 72-76 days to mature. The plants are compact plant 50 to 60 cm in height, bearing 12 x 9 cm fruit that turns red at maturity. ‘Capistrano’ is resistant to Tobamovirus.

en.name: Caribbean Red
en.description: 'Caribbean Red' is an open-pollinated, habañero hot pepper that takes about 90-100 days to mature. The fruit can grow to about 5 cm in length and 2.5 cm in diameter, they are wrinkled and mature from green to a unique red.  This is an extremely hot habanero pepper with a Scoville Rating of 445,600.

en.name: Habanero Hot
en.description: 'Caribbean Red' is an open-pollinated, habañero hot pepper that takes about 90-100 days to mature. The fruit can grow to about 5 cm in length and 2.5 cm in diameter, they are wrinkled and mature from green to a unique red.  This is an extremely hot habanero pepper with a Scoville Rating of 445,600.

en.name: Ensalada
en.description: 'Ensalada' peppers are a dooryard variety from Jamaica selected for the size of their edible leaves, which are eaten cooked. They are more drought resistant that other hot peppers.

en.name: Red Mix
en.description: ‘Red Mix’ is a mix of at least two lines of seed originating in Venezuela and producing somewhat bushy plants reaching 0.9-1.2m in height.

en.name: Indian Firecracker
en.description: 'Indian Firecracker' is a perennial, hot, 'bush' pepper from India. The second generation of seed at ECHO has resulted in large (1.7m tall), high-yielding plants. This pepper produces very attractive, pungent (hot - Scoville rating of 30,000 - 50,000), 2.5 - 5cm long fruits on plants that live several years when protected from frost.

en.name: Serrano Chili
en.description: ‘Serrano Chilli’ is an open-pollinated, hot pepper, that takes about 80-85 days to maturity. The club shaped fruit is around 5 cm in length and 1.5 cm in diameter, with medium to thin walls, and good for pickling and salsa. (Scoville rating of 2,500-4,000).

en.name: Green
en.description: The 'Green' variety produces plants that have a milder taste than the red-variegated type.

en.name: Mixed
en.description: ‘Mixed’ is a mix of both the green and red variegated Lagos Spinach types in our seed bank.

en.name: Cavalcade/Centro
en.description: ‘Cavalcade’ is an early flowering variety of this fast growing forage species. It is well-suited to regions having short growing seasons with low wet season rainfall (700-900 mm annually).

en.name: Wynn
en.description: 'Wynn' is used primarily as a pasture legume but it has potential use as a forage crop. It has been successfully introduced as a self-seeding annual into drier regions of northern Queensland, Australia, that receive only about 600 mm of annual rainfall.

en.name: Colorado 407
en.description: 'Colorado 407' was developed at Colorado State University from Chilean races and is day-neutral. It has been a top producer at ECHO Florida with smaller, yellow-colored seed. The plants can grow to a height of nearly 2 m.

en.name: UC-27
en.description: 'UC-27' was developed at the University of California, Davis. It is a large-seeded garbanzo bean resistant to fusarium wilt.

en.name: Crimson Sweet
en.description: 'Crimson Sweet' is an open pollinated variety that takes about 85 days to maturity. The fruit is near-round, 40 X 35 cm, weighing up to 12 kgs, and is medium green with dark green stripes.

en.name: Honey Rock
en.description: ‘Honey Rock’ cantaloupes are slightly oval, with thick, firm, sweet, salmon-orange colored flesh. Fruits can weigh up to 1.5 kg, and take about 85 days to maturity. This variety is somewhat resistant to Fusarium Wilt.

en.name: Marketmore 76
en.description: 'Marketmore 76' is an open-pollinated, mid-sized, slicing cucumber, with a uniform dark green color. This variety takes about 68 days to maturity, and is resistant to cucumber mosaic virus, downy mildew, powdery mildew, and scab.

en.name: Seminole
en.description: 'Seminole' is a generic variety of Seminole pumpkin with relatively small fruits on vigorous vines that grow up to 3 m long.

en.name: Acorn
en.description: 'Acorn' is a great tasting, and high yielding selection of Seminole pumpkin from ECHO's seed bank.

en.name: Crookneck
en.description: 'Crookneck' produces a large number of oblong, orange, pumpkins with light orange flesh that matures in about 90 days.

en.name: Ingram Billie
en.description: 'Ingram Billie' is a land race of Seminole pumpkins that produces a large number of small pumpkins with variable fruit size.

en.name: Mix
en.description: ‘Seminole Mix’ is a mix of all Seminole pumpkin varieties currently in the seed bank (Acorn, Ingram Billie and Crookneck).

en.name: Brian
en.description: ECHO's "Brian" variety is beige, round and thick-fleshed.

en.name: Tahitian Butternut
en.description: 'Tahitian Butternut' pumpkins have large, long necks with dark orange flesh and mature in about 110 days. When crossed with other varieties, the pumpkin shape become highly variable.

en.name: Trinidad
en.description: 'Trinidad', originally from Trinidad via Hope Seeds, has dark green skin, and deep orange, sweet interior flesh. The vigorous vines requires ample space for optimal growth. The ground mark will change color from light green to cream to deep orange indicating when the fruit is ready for harvest.

en.name: Early Prolific Straightneck
en.description: ‘Early Prolific Straightneck’ is an open-pollinated summer squash. This is an early producing variety with large yellow fruits.

en.name: Black Beauty
en.description: 'Black Beauty' is a classic dark-green, open-pollinated, summer squash, that has made modern zucchini of this type popular.

en.name: Danvers 126
en.description: ‘Danvers 126' is an open-pollinated midseason variety that is durable, bolt hardy, and strong tops.

en.name: Large Red Pod
en.description: ‘Large Red Pod' produces larger calyxes than the ‘Thai Red’ variety. The plants can grow to a height of 2 meters or more.

en.name: Thai Red
en.description: ‘Thai Red’ displays compact growth, early flowering, more tart calyxes, and less proclivity to leaf chlorosis compared to varieties. It is our best performer at ECHO Florida.

en.name: PKM 1
en.description: 'PKM-1' was selected for bushier growth. Produces more heavily than other oleifera species. Eat leaves like spinach; young pods cooked like asparagus.

en.name: PKM-1 1kg
en.description: 'PKM-1' was selected for bushier growth. Produces more heavily than other oleifera species. Eat leaves like spinach; young pods cooked like asparagus.

en.name: PKM-1 50g
en.description: 'PKM-1' was selected for bushier growth. Produces more heavily than other oleifera species. Eat leaves like spinach; young pods cooked like asparagus.

en.name: Uberlandia
en.description: ‘Uberlandia' is a tropical carrot variety which sets seed in one year and which was selected for good performance in the lowland tropics.

en.name: Uberlandia Reed-Franz Improved
en.description: ‘Uberlandia Reed-Franz Improved' carrots are similar to 'Uberlandia', but have been further selected by an ECHO volunteer, Reed Franz for bolting in warm weather.

en.name: Scarlet Nantes
en.description: ‘Scarlet Nantes' are open-pollinated carrots are nearly coreless, orange, averaging 15 cm  long and mature in about 75 days. This is perhaps the best variety for cooler areas in the tropics or highland areas and also does well in clay soil.

en.name: Brown/Red
en.description: 'Brown/Red' is a hardier and faster maturing variety, taking about 4 months to mature. Historically it has grown better than 'White' at ECHO Florida.

en.name: White
en.description: 'White' is the most common variety on the market.

en.name: Gliricidia
en.description: This is a generic selection of Gliricidia sepium.

en.name: Retalhuleu
en.description: 'Retalhuleu' is a variety from Guatemala known for high leaf and wood production.

en.name: Braxton
en.description: 'Braxton'  is developed for temperate areas, and is worth attempting in high altitude locations.

en.name: Early Hakucho
en.description: 'Early Hakucho' has bright green pods about 6 mm long, is not a short-day plant, and can be used as a vegetable when picked green. This is a dwarf variety, maturing in about 75 days, and proves reliable even when the growing season is short.

en.name: Kahala
en.description: 'Kahala' is a nematode-resistant tropical soybean developed in Hawaii that takes 60-90 days to mature.

en.name: Lucky Lion
en.description: 'Lucky Lion' is a high yielding, vegetable soybean with vivid green pods containing 2 or 3 seeds that matures in about 75 days. High yielding.

en.name: Russian Mammoth
en.description: 'Russian Mammoth' produces white and black edible seeds on the largest sunflower heads at ECHO Florida. ‘Skyscraper’ is the only variety that grows taller.

en.name: Sunspot
en.description: ‘Sunspot' is a dwarf confection sunflower producing 20 to 30 cm heads filled with edible seeds.

en.name: Peredovik
en.description: 'Peredovik' is a Russian oilseed sunflower that matures in about 110 days. It is grown for quality cooking oil.

en.name: Rostov
en.description: 'Rostov' is an oilseed variety that produces very large, 30 cm heads on 2 m, sturdy, wind resistant stalks.

en.name: Everglades 41
en.description: ‘Everglades 41’ is a short-day variety developed for latitudes between 10° to 27° N or S. If grown in the tropics this variety will flower between 60 to 80 days from planting producing shorter plants with less fiber production.

en.name: SF-459
en.description: ‘SF459’ is also a short-day variety of kenaf that is resistant to southern root-knot nematode and several soil-borne fungal diseases in Florida.

en.name: Chiang Dao
en.description: 'Chiang Dao' is a white field lablab with white flowers collected by ECHO asia staff from Chiang Dao district in Thailand.

en.name: Highworth
en.description: 'Highworth' was introduced to Australia from Southern India. It is an early flowering variety with purple flowers and black seeds produced in non-shattering pods.

en.name: Mix
en.description: 'Mix' contains several lablab varieties from ECHO including ''Rongai' (white flowers and light brown seeds), 'Highworth' (purple flowers and dark seeds) and 'White' (white seeds).

en.name: Red Hyacinth
en.description: 'Red Hyacinth'  is a day-neutral lablab that has red stems with large scarlet pods that can be eaten when immature.

en.name: Ruby Moon
en.description: 'Ruby Moon' grows on a vigorous vine, with purple to red seed pods and flowers. The seeds, young leaves, and flowers are eaten, and the plant is used as a green manure/cover crop.

en.name: Rongai
en.description: 'Rongai' is a forage and green manure/cover crop variety with white flowers and light brown, edible seeds.

en.name: White
en.description: 'White' is a forage and food variety with large, edible, white seeds.

en.name: Anuenue
en.description: 'Anuenue'  resembles small iceberg lettuce but is more heat resistant, It has thick, crisp, bright green outer leaves surrounding a large well-packed heart that has a mild and juicy flavor. This lettuce was developed at the University of Hawaii and matures in 50-54 days.

en.name: Ithaca
en.description: 'Ithaca' lettuce was first developed at Cornell University and named after the town. It is a medium to large-sized, smooth, flattened head, with green frilled leaves that takes 53 to 85 days to mature.

en.name: New Red Fire
en.description: 'New Red Fire' is a large, semi-heading variety, with large, deep red, ruffled leaves that hold color even in adverse conditions. Plants uniformly produce the same size heads in 43 to 65 days.

en.name: Queensland
en.description: 'Queensland' lettuce, from Australia, is a slow-bolting, heat resistant cos (romaine) type lettuce.

en.name: Tall Guzmaine
en.description: 'Tall Guzmaine' is a romaine lettuce with dark green, blistered leaves. This variety has some resistance to lettuce mosaic virus.

en.name: Crimson
en.description: 'Crimson' is a drought-resistant Middle Eastern variety that blooms early.

en.name: K156
en.description: ‘K156’ was an accession of L. diversifolia from Veracruz, Mexico that was widely distributed by the University of Hawaii. It is very susceptible to psyllid damage

en.name: K784
en.description: ‘K784’ has proven to be the most psyllid resistant variety of L. diversifolia.

en.name: K6 Peruvian
en.description: 'K6' is a variety of L. leucocephala from Peru that exhibits excessive branching and much foliage. This variety will grow very tall unless pruned or coppiced and is usually used for forage.

en.name: K8
en.description: 'K8' is a variety of L. leucocephala that is used mainly for timber. It is of the Hawaiian giant or Salvador type and can grow to 20 m height in five years.

en.name: K67
en.description: 'K67' is a variety of L. leucocephala bred for seed production, timber and fuelwood. It is a Hawaiian Giant type bred in El Salvador.

en.name: KX2 Hawaii
en.description: ‘KX2’ is a hybrid of L.pallida and L. leucocephala developed at the University of Hawaii. It has excellent psyllid resistance, cold tolerance, and is suited for elevations between sea level and 1000 m.

en.name: Ameristand 403T
en.description: ‘Ameristand 403T’ is an extremely high yielding traffic tolerant alfalfa that can be grazed heavily.  403T is best suited for cool climate areas.

en.name: Ameristand 803T
en.description: ‘Ameristand 803T’ alfalfa has excellent resistance to pests and traffic and produces high yields for pasture grazing and hay production.

en.name: Bulldog 505
en.description: ‘Bulldog 505’ was developed at the University of Georgia and is suited to slightly warmer areas than the AmeriStand varieties. It is grazing tolerant and produces good yields of excellent hay. This variety is resistant to Fusarium Wilt and Phytophthora root rot.

en.name: 90-Day
en.description: ‘90-Day’ is a day-length neutral variety that is less vigorous than tropical variety. This variety has irritating hairs so skin should be protected during harvesting.

en.name: Cooper
en.description: 'Cooper' is an early flowering, drought-resistant, perennial vining variety of Gycine.

en.name: Italian Large Leaf
en.description: ‘Italian Large Leaf’ is a commercial variety that is slow to bolt and has uniform, dark green, broad leaves.

en.name: Vulgare type
en.description: Our oregano variety is bright blue-green with aromatic, flavorful leaves which can be used fresh or dried.

en.name: White
en.description: ‘White’ proso millet is a generic white-seeded variety that is preferred over dark-seeded cultivars for both birdseed and human consumption.

en.name: Candlestick
en.description: ‘Candlestick’ is an open-pollinated grain variety of pearl millet suitable for human consumption.

en.name: Tifleaf 3
en.description: ‘Tifleaf 3’ is a hybrid pearl millet that is short, very leafy, and used strictly for forage.

en.name: Dark Green Italian
en.description: ‘Dark Green Italian’ is a fancy, wide leaf variety, with broad, smooth, glossy leaves.

en.name: Black
en.description: The ‘Black’ variety of tepary beans is rust and blight resistant, and BGMV (Bean Golden Mosaic Virus) tolerant.

en.name: Brown/Yellow
en.description: The  'Brown/Yellow' variety of tepary beans will recover faster from wilt, are blight resistant, and are also BGMV (Bean Golden Mosaic Virus) tolerant.

en.name: Mix
en.description: 'Mix' is a mixture of several tepary bean varieties.

en.name: Tan
en.description: The 'Tan' variety of tepary beans were bred in Puerto Rico for BGMV (Bean Golden Mosaic Virus) tolerance and high yields.

en.name: Tan/Grey
en.description: 'Tan/Grey' tepary beans are wilt tolerant and resistant to blight and rust.

en.name: Tohono O'odham Brown
en.description: 'Tohono O'odham Brown' is a brown tepary bean bred by the Tohono O'odham Nation in the Sonoran Desert of Arizona, USA and Northern Mexico.

en.name: White
en.description: 'White' tepary beans are noted as ECHO's most drought-tolerant variety.

en.name: Yoeme
en.description: 'Yoeme' tepary beans are named after the Yaqui or Yoeme people who live in the river valley of the Rio Yaqui in Northern Mexico.

en.name: Hopi Red
Pima Beige
en.description: ‘Pima Beige’ is an indeterminate, deep-rooted, climbing, small-seeded lima from Arizona that produces seeds that are beige with dark speckles.

en.name: Pima Orange
en.description: ‘Pima Orange’ is an indeterminate, deep-rooted, climbing, small-seeded lima from Arizona that produces seeds that are orange with dark speckles.

en.name: Oregon Sugar Pod II
en.description: ‘Oregon Sugar Pod II’ produces light green, edible flat pods, with a mild sweet flavor. The pods are up to 10 cm in length on vines up to a meter in height.. Snow pea . This variety is resistant to common wilt, pea mosaic virus, and powdery mildew.

en.name: Mammoth Melting
en.description: 'Mammoth Melting' produces an abundant crop of delicious, succulent, 10 cm edible pods on 1.25 m long, trellised vines.

en.name: Red
en.description: ‘Red’ is the red-fruited variety of cattley guava.

en.name: Yellow
en.description: ‘Yellow’ is the yellow-fruited variety of cattley guava.

en.name: Ruby X Supreme
en.description: ‘Ruby X Supreme’ is a hybrid cross between the ‘Ruby’ and ‘Supreme’ cultivars. The fruits  are small, roundish, with greenish-yellow skin, and dark pink-orange, delicious flesh. The tree  is bushy, low growing, with vigorous, drooping branches.

en.name: Bogor
en.description: 'Bogor' is a short day-length variety, with very vigorous vines, 20 cm pods, and high yields.

en.name: Chimbu
en.description: 'Chimbu' has crimson red pods, purple seed, medium yields.

en.name: Day Neutral
en.description: ‘Day-Neutral’ blooms during longer days, allowing out of season production.

en.name: Flat
en.description: ‘Flat’ produces easy to transport pods due to shape. This variety needs shorter days to produce seed.

en.name: Mix
en.description: ‘Mix' is a mixture of ECHO's winged bean varieties. If you are unsure which variety may work in your area, we recommend requesting this mixture.

en.name: Ribbon
en.description: ‘Ribbon’ has smaller wings, 23 cm green pods, and needs shorter days to produce seed.

en.name: Siempre
en.description: ‘Siempre’ produces pods that are smaller than most other varieties and has good tuber production.

en.name: Square
en.description: ‘Square' has good tuber production during the shorter, cooler days.

en.name: Thai
en.description: 'Thai' has longer, thin leaves that set this variety apart from others and originates from lines bred in southeast Asia.

en.name: Champion
en.description: ‘Champion’ produces bright red radishes with strong tops for upland soils. This open-pollinated  variety requires 28 days until harvest and is good for bunching and shipping.

en.name: Daikon
en.description: Daikons are also called Japanese radishes, store well, and are primarily white-skinned, and larger, longer, coarser, and  take longer to mature than red varieties.

en.name: Tropical
en.description: Climbing variety. Requires short days for flower and pod production.

en.name: Monkey Thorn
en.description: A very tall deciduous African acacia adapted to hot dry climates with bottle-brush cream flowers. Native to South and East Africa growing in open areas near streams and bodies of water. Primarily used as a fast-growing timber species for shade, animal fodder and seeds. Can tolerate mild freezing conditions once mature. Seeds are flat circular shaped with an interior loop attached near the hilum. Trees may reach 20-30m in height.

en.name: Evergreen Hardy White
en.description: ‘Evergreen Hardy White’ is an heirloom variety from Japan that matures in 65 days.

en.name: Black
en.description: 'Black' pigeon peas have historically grown very well at ECHO Florida. They produce black seeds and like other pigeon peas are perennial shrubs that produce green or dried beans in seasonally dry climates.

en.name: Caqui
en.description: ‘Caqui’ is a long duration, indeterminate pigeon pea variety that produces abundant pods of creamy, white-colored seeds. As well as human consumption it is used for intercropping, green manure and fodder.

en.name: ICPL 92016
en.description: 'ICPL 92016' pigeon pea was developed by ICRISAT (International Crops Research Institute for Semi-Arid Tropics) in India. It is a short-duration pigeon pea (100-140 days to maturity), growing to 1.5 m in height, that produces an abundant crop of pods and seeds. At ECHO, this variety survived Hurricane Charley in 2004, recovering quite well despite being completely flattened.

en.name: Mix
en.description: 'Mix', a mix of various pigeon peas in our collection. This mix contains some short duration and some long duration (daylength sensitive) pigeon pea varieties.  Varieties included are 'Georgia Two', 'ICPL 8151', 'Agroforestry Select' and 'Caqui'. Mixes are useful for trying out different types to see which grow best in a specific location.

en.name: ICPL 88034 -- Early Maturing
en.description: 'ICPL 88034 - Early Maturing' originates from part of a germplasm collection in India. Days to 50% flowering is 61 days, which is earlier than long duration varieties. Days to maturity is 115 days. This variety also shows day-neutral characteristics.

en.name: Green Senagalese
en.description: ‘Green Senegalese’ has green edible leaves that used in dishes in Senegal. The green calyxes of this variety are not as tart nor as sweet nor as fleshy as the calyxes of the red roselle.

en.name: PKM-2
en.description: ‘PKM-2’ is similar to the ‘PKM-1’ except that the pods of the PKM-2 are longer and fleshier. Eat leaves like spinach; young pods cooked like asparagus.

en.name: Green/Viridis
en.description: 'Green/Viridis' is the green version of Love-Lies-Bleeding and can grow to 2 m in height. This variety produces long, green tassels of seed that are used in flower arrangements either fresh, cut, or dried. The grain and leaves are also edible.

en.planting_instructions: Plant 2 cm deep in well-drained soil.
en.name: Short Duration Vegetable
en.description: This variety is drought tolerant, and used for intercropping, green manure, fodder.The young peas and dried beans are edible and nutritious.

en.planting_instructions: Plant 2 cm deep, 35 cm apart in 65 cm rows. Harvest regularly to encourage production, starting at 60 days.
en.name: Burmese
en.description: ‘Burmese’ is a less mucilaginous variety with large 40 cm leaves that bears when plants are 45 cm tall. The spineless pods are best when harvested when less than 25 cm long.

en.name: Jamaican Callaloo
en.description: 'Jamaican Callaloo' is a common dooryard variety of green leaf amaranth (A. viridis).

en.planting_instructions: Okra seeds require warm soils, 15°C or higher, for germination and grow best in full sun during warm months. Soak seeds overnight for a fast start. Plant 1.5 to 2 cm deep and 70-80 cm apart in rows 1.5 to 2 m apart in well-drained composted soil in rows. Okra needs full sun. Best okra soils are loose, well drained, and humus rich. Addition of surface mulch is desirable for weed control.
en.name: Gumby
en.description: 'Gumby' - is a further selection of the 'Prelude' variety of okra. It matures much earlier and at a shorter height than other varieties of okra.

en.name: American Flag
en.description: ‘American Flag’ is an heirloom variety that was bred for cold northeast US winters.

en.name: Custard Apple
en.description: Custard apple is a medium sized, semi-deciduous tree, up to 10 m in height, with large yellow-brown custard textured fruit. The fruit can be up to 15 cm in diameter, has a sweet flavor, and is usually consumed fresh.

en.name: Snowball Y Improved
en.description: 'Snowball Y Improved' is an open pollinated cauliflower that was introduced into states in 1888. It produces large, white heads in 50 to 70 days.

en.name: White Vienna
en.description: 'White Vienna' is an open-pollinated, heirloom variety that is ready to harvest in about 58 days.

en.name: Mae John
en.description: ‘Mae John’ is the larger-seeded variety, obtained from Thailand, and used for food.

en.name: Small Seeded
en.description: 'Small Seeded' Job's tears has smaller seeds than the Mae John variety and is used for decorative purposes.

en.name: Mix
en.description: 'Mix' These cosmos flowers have pink, yellow, white and orange blooms and will grow 1-2 m tall.

en.name: Green Stripe
en.description: 'Green Stripe' is a very large, white, cushaw pumpkin, with green stripes and coloration that originated in Central America. This variety produces 5-10 kg fruit in tropical areas.

en.name: Yahola
en.description: 'Yahola' is a variety of Seminole pumpkin that is named after a native Seminole war cry used during the Seminole wars who were under the leadership of Asi-Yahola. This plant produces multiple, small, cream-colored fruit that weigh an average of 1 kg.

en.name: Tong Ho
en.description: 'Tong Ho' is a variety of edible chrysanthemum.  Edible chrysanthemum is also known as shungiku or garland chrysanthemum. 'Tong Ho' produces large, smooth leaves that add flavor to stir-fries, soups and salads; great spicy, sweet, aromatic taste. It also produces lovely yellow flowers. Sow 0.6 cm (1/4 in) deep in soil. Keep trimmed back for more foliage.

en.name: Tohya
en.description: ‘Tohya’ is an early maturing, vegetable soybean, with a delicious, buttery flavor, and tender-firm texture.

en.name: Kagraner Sommer
en.description: ‘Kagraner Sommer’ is an heirloom butterhead lettuce from Germany that is resistant to heat and produces elegant, pale green heads, of exceptional quality. It matures in about 58 days.

en.name: Crackerjack Mix
en.description: 'Crackerjack Mix' marigolds are a hardy annual native to South and Central America. This heirloom variety grows to 0.9m in height and its blooms are yellow to deep orange.

en.name: Buffalo Thorn
en.description: Buffalo thorn is a thorny, bushy shrub or small tree of semi-arid climates, growing to 12 m in height. It is used for its edible fruit and livestock browsing. The tree is good bee forage, and makes good firewood, charcoal, fence posts and furniture. Because of its thorns and tangled branches, the tree makes an effective thorn branch fence and can also be used as a component of live fences.

en.name: ECHO Bush Selection #1
en.description: ‘ECHO #1’ is a bush type selected by the University of Florida from ECHO seeds for bush habit and for an abundance of pods.

en.name: Beefsteak
en.description: 'Beefsteak' is an open pollinated large tomato that requires 85 days to maturity. It is an old standard variety with a beautiful deep red fruit that has a superb classic tomato taste.

en.name: Caro Rich
en.description: ‘Caro Rich’ is an open-pollinated, determinate, large, smooth, globe-shaped, beefsteak-type, with 280 to 340 g. fruits that have 10 times as much as beta carotene as other tomatoes. This variety is very low in acid and requires 80 days to maturity.

en.name: Delicious
en.description: ‘Delicious’ is a medium-large, indeterminate, red slicing tomato developed from the ‘Beefsteak’ variety and takes 77 days to maturity.

en.name: Floradade
en.description: ‘Floradade’ us an open-pollinated, determinate variety developed by the University of Florida. It is resistant to Verticillium and Fusarium Wilt Races 1 & 2, and Gray Leafspot. It can be grown free-standing or staked and takes 80-85 days to maturity.

en.name: Hayslip
en.description: 'Hayslip' is an open-pollinated, determinate tomato, developed by the University of Florida that matures in 70 to 80 days and shows resistance to Verticillium and Fusarium Wilt, Grey Leafspot, Blossom end rot, Black shoulder, Catface and cracking.

en.name: Homestead
en.description: ‘Homestead’ is a semi-determinate, wilt resistant, productive tomato with firm, tasty flesh that is ready in 80-83 days.

en.name: Komohana
en.description: ‘Komohana’ is an open-pollinated, determinate, red grape tomato from Hawaii that produces prolifically in 75-80 days.

en.name: Matt's Wild Cherry
en.description: ‘Matt’s Wild Cherry’ is an indeterminate variety that yields deep-red, round fruits 0.5 cm-2 cm in diameter that have a tender, smooth texture, and loads of sweet flavor. This variety shows some resistance to early blight and late blight. Fruits split easily and are not good for market sale.

en.name: Roma VFN
en.description: 'Roma VFN' is an open-pollinated, indeterminate, red, pear shaped fruit used fresh or for paste. It is disease resistant and matures in approximately 78 days.

en.name: Tropic
en.description: 'Tropic' is a large, indeterminate tomato, developed by the University of Florida. The plants should be staked for high yields of pinkish fruit starting at about 80 days. It is resistant to Verticillium wilt, Fusarium wilt, Grey Leaf Spot, Graywall, Tobacco Mosaic Virus, and Leaf molds.

en.name: Walter
en.description: 'Walter' is an open-pollinated, determinate variety developed at the University of Florida Bradenton experiment station by Dr. Walter. It is resistant to Fusarium Wilt Races 1 & 2, and to Gray Leaf Spot.The red fruit, weighing approximately 225 grams matures in about 75 days.

en.name: Yellow Pear
en.description: ‘Yellow Pear’ is a small, yellow, determinate, roma style fruit.

en.name: Florida Market
en.description: 'Florida Market' is an open-pollinated, large, purple eggplant, maturing in 78-90 days. It is resistant to Phomopsis blight and fruit rot.

en.name: Jilo
en.description: ‘Jilo’ is a large, woody eggplant, with fist-sized, red fruits, and very fuzzy purple green leaves.

en.name: Long White
en.description: 'Long White' variety was found in Indonesia and has been a staple eggplant at ECHO since 1987. The fruits are 20-25 cm long, solid white fading to yellow when mature or over mature.

en.name: Pingtung Long
en.description: 'Pingtung Long' is a  long, slender, oriental variety, resistant to many diseases and a favorite at  ECHO. The fruit is purple with white stripes, slender, straight, 20 cm long, and 3.5 cm in diameter.

en.name: Rosa Bianca
en.description: ‘Rosa Bianca’ is a small, 10-15 cm round eggplant, with pale purple skin, and delicate flavor without bitterness. It was a top performer in an ECHO variety trial and matures in 80-90 days.

en.name: Yellow
en.description: ‘Yellow’ is very productive in hot, humid weather. The fruit is green, turning yellow when mature. It has proven productive at ECHO even when affected by nematodes.

en.name: Julio Rivera
en.description: This variety from Puerto Rico has fewer spines on the leaves than regular naranjilla. The fruits are bright orange and thick-skinned with greenish pulp.

en.name: Bird-resistant
en.description: 'Bird-resistant' is a dwarf, white-seeded variety, developed at Purdue University. This variety  contains tannins, giving the unripened grain a bitter taste which leads to its resistance to bird damage. The tannin content decreases as the grain matures. Tannin is low when grain reaches 16-18% moisture content. WARNING!! Don't roast unripe seedheads which may still contain toxins.

en.name: Broomcorn
en.description: 'Broom Corn' was the traditional source of fiber for brooms and brushes, and the stalks, which can grow to 2 to 5 m tall, can also be used to make paper.

en.name: Giza 114
en.description: 'Giza 114', from Egypt, is a solid-stalked grain sorghum. The stalks are suitable as a fuel source.

en.name: Grain/Forage
en.description: 'Grain/Forage' is primarily used for forage and animal feed, but the grain is also suitable for human consumption.

en.name: M91051
en.description: 'M91051' is a variety, originally from Purdue University, that was one of the top performers during trials in Haiti, maturing two months earlier than other Haitian varieties.

en.name: Red's Red Sweet
en.description: 'Red's Red Sweet' is a variety of sweet sorghum, grown for syrup production, that performs well at ECHO Florida.

en.name: Striga-resistant
en.description: 'Striga-resistant', developed at Purdue University, is resistant to the parasitic weed Striga, and produces good grain for feed on plants about 1.25 m tall.

en.name: Mineirao
en.description: 'Mineirao' variety takes about 120 days to become established as a low growing crop with a spreading habit. It is grown as a semi-erect perennial and produces good yields from sea level up to 2,000 m, between 900-2,000 mm rainfall, and temperatures between 18-28 degrees C.

en.name: Fine Stem Stylo
en.description: 'Fine stem stylo' is a variety that is slow growing for the first 6 weeks, cannot stand heavy grazing and does best at higher altitudes with heavy rainfall.

en.name: Amiga
en.description: 'Amiga' is a stylo best suited to the hot tropics with 600-1,700 mm rainfall in a growing season of 15-25 weeks. Caribbean stylo is tolerant of acidic soils, but is limited to low altitude regions because it is subject to frost damage.

en.name: Blue Flowered
en.description: 'Blue Flowered' is a variety that has light blue/purple blossoms.

en.name: White Flowered
en.description: 'White Flowered' is a variety that has white blossoms.

en.name: Osceola
en.description: 'Osceola' is a variety developed by the University of Florida as a higher yielding, more persistent improvement of White Louisiana S-1. It is a perennial warm-climate clover suitable for tropical highlands, however it cannot tolerate long, dry seasons and remain a perennial.

en.name: Sweet Lorane
en.description: 'Sweet Lorane' is a medium sized fava that is both a cover crop and was selected for its sweet flavor, making it an excellent choice as a dual purpose crop.

en.name: Green
en.description: ‘Green’ is a slender, twining vine that does better on a trellis if available.

en.name: Bush
en.description: ‘Bush’ is a type of rice bean growing 30-75 cm tall, and does not require a trellis. It can be grown as an annual or perennial.

en.name: Baby Cream
en.description: ‘Baby Cream’ is a variety released from the USDA vegetable laboratory in Charleston, South Carolina. It forms compact, erect plants, with small, delicate, cream-type peas. This variety is resistant to lodging and root-knot nematodes, and performs well under hot and humid conditions.

en.name: Bettergro Blackeye Pea
en.description: ‘Bettergro Blackeye’ is resistant to cowpea curculio and root knot nematodes, but is susceptible to cowpea mosaic virus.

en.name: Charleston Blackeye
en.description: ‘Charleston Blackeye’ is a root-knot nematode resistant variety released from the USDA vegetable laboratory in Charleston, South Carolina. It has upright growth, and cream colored black eyed peas.

en.name: ILCA
en.description: ‘ILCA’ is a forage variety originally from Mali, and selected by the International Livestock Center for Africa. It is a bushy plant with compact pods, can be used as a green manure and cover crop, and is a drought-tolerant forage or edible pulse.

en.name: Mavuno
en.description: 'Mavuno' is the best local variety from Magu, Tanzania.  The plants grow as creeping vines with large leaves and large, long pods that contain cream colored seeds.

en.name: Reddish Brown
en.description: 'Reddish Brown' is the variety that performs the best at ECHO in Florida's humid climate. This variety matures in about 70 days.

en.name: Samoeng
en.description: 'Samoeng' is a short, creeping cowpea vine that produces plump pods with black seeds, and is often intercropped with upland rice. It is a good variety as an understory for other crops as it fixes nitrogen and shades out weeds.

en.name: Thailand Long
en.description: 'Thailand Long' was obtained from a missionary in Thailand in the late 1980's. This variety was selected for longer pods, and has a bush-like habit, growing close to the ground. This cowpea works well as a cover crop.

en.name: Green Arrow
en.description: ‘Green Arrow’ produces abundant slender, light green pods, up to 50 cm long, on a climbing or trailing vine.

en.name: Green Pod Kaohsiung
en.description: ‘Green Pod Kaohsiung’  is a heat and wet-tolerant variety, producing long, slender, round pods that are typically about 50 cm long.

en.name: Guilin
en.description: 'Guilin' is a variety from China with long, thin pods. This was a very productive variety in a trial at ECHO.

en.name: KY Bush
en.description: ‘KY Bush’ is an early variety, resistant to insects and viruses. The plants are very vigorous, dwarf (approx. 50c m) and well-branched. The pods are slender, light green, 25-30cm. long, tender and stringless with red seeds.

en.name: Mix
en.description: ‘Mix’ contains a mixture of several red, purple and green yard long bean varieties.

en.name: Purple Mart
en.description: 'Purple Mart' is a long, purple, disease resistant variety.

en.name: Purple-Podded
en.description: ‘Purple-Podded’ is a productive variety, maturing in 80-90 days. The attractive, purple color remains after cooking. The pods are shorter than the  green-podded varieties.

en.name: Red Noodle
en.description: 'Red Noodle' is a long, red podded variety. The red beans and pods lose their color when cooked.

en.name: Hawaiian Supersweet #9
en.description: ‘Hawaiian Supersweet #9’ is an open-pollinated, yellow sweet corn developed by the University of Hawaii, specifically for the tropics. This variety matures in 68-75 days.

en.name: Hawaiian Supersweet #9 Silver
en.description: 'Hawaiian Supersweet Silver #9' is an open-pollinated, white sweet corn variety from the University of Hawaii with 75% tropical parentage. This variety is resistant to corn borer and maize mosaic virus.

en.name: Quality Protein
en.description: ‘Quality Protein' maize is higher in the amino acid lysine than other maize varieties. This variety must be grown in isolation to maintain the quality protein content.

en.name: Rio Grande Red
en.description: ‘Rio Grande Red’, also known as ‘Bloody Mary’ was developed in New Mexico (USA). This variety dries well and makes a nice flour, and is also  used for livestock feed. It grows to less than 2 meters in height producing 1-2 ears with white-spotted red kernels in about 110 days.

en.name: Contender
en.description: ‘Contender’ is grown mainly as a green bean but beans may be eaten dry. It takes 55 days to maturity with pods averaging 16cm in length. It is resistant to powdery mildew and bean mosaic virus.

en.name: Tio Canela
en.description: ‘Tio Canela’ is a small, red-seeded variety, harvested as a dry bean at 4-5 months after planting. This variety is noted for its resistance to bean golden yellow mosaic virus.

en.name: Sparky Mix
en.description: 'Sparky Mix' is an heirloom variety that grows to 15-45cm in height and produces orange/red blooms throughout the season.

en.name: Extra Large
en.description: ‘Extra Large’ is a large, flat, creamy seeded variety. The beans are edible only after soaking for several days in salted water. Warning: Those with a peanut allergy should exercise caution as lupine, being related to peanuts, can cause an allergic reaction on first exposure.

en.name: Chiang Mai
en.description: Fruit is about 13 cm in length and 10 cm in diameter.

en.name: Dove
en.description: ‘Dove’ proso millet was released in 1972 by the Natural Resources Conservation Service (NRCS) mainly as feed for dove and quail. It matures in 65 to 75 days and has excellent growth and seed production.

en.name: Yellow Passionfruit
en.description: Yellow passionfruit is a perennial climbing vine, up to 15 m in length, bearing fruits up to 7 cm in diameter. The pulp and seeds may be eaten fresh or the seeds may be removed to eat or use in beverages. Yellow passionfruit is adapted to a more tropical and lowland climate than the purple variety and is considered a possible mutant of purple passionfruit.

en.name: IS 12965
en.description: 'IS12965' was selected at ICRISAT, but thought to originate from Cuba. It was a top performer and favorite variety of Haitian farmers during trials in Haiti in 2005.

en.name: Stylo Mix
en.description: ‘Stylo Mix’ contains both Stylosanthes capitata & S. macrocephala.
‘83060’ is a variety from Nigeria that shows resistance to insects and disease.

en.name: Mix
en.description: ‘Mix’ is a selection of 5 different quick producing cowpea varieties.

en.name: Cubano Argentino
en.description: ‘Cubano Argentino’, one of the parents of Tex Cuban maize, is an open-pollinated, tropical, yellow kernel maize useful for silage and feed. This variety has done well on the ECHO farm in the 2-4-2 maize trials.  It is dependable and has shown resistance to lodging even with heavy rain and wind. It performs well in day-neutral zones. If used in more temperate zones the plant will achieve tall green growth but will not tassel until day length shortens to 14 hours.

en.name: Painted Mountain
en.description: ‘Painted Mountain Corn’ was developed by corn breeder Dave Christensen to grow quite far north in the USA. This variety is very rugged and productive in northern climates tolerating drought and cold. It matures in 70-90 days.

en.name: Tex Cuban
en.description: ‘Tex-Cuban’ is an open-pollinated maize, developed by the University of Florida, that produces a white flint type kernel. This is a superior silage variety selected for high yield and nutrient content. The robust plant grows to a height of 4 meters, is tolerant of insects and diseases, and is adapted to heat and late season planting.

en.name: California Giants
en.description: 'California Giants' is a mix of large zinnia flowers.

en.name: Persian (seedless)
en.description: ‡∏°‡∏∞‡∏ô‡∏≤‡∏ß‡πÑ‡∏£‡πâ‡πÄ‡∏°‡πá‡∏î

en.name: Persian (Phaen)
en.description: ‡∏°‡∏∞‡∏ô‡∏≤‡∏ß‡πÅ‡∏õ‡πâ‡∏ô

en.name: Tahiti
en.description: ‡∏°‡∏∞‡∏ô‡∏≤‡∏ß

en.name: Haba
en.description: 'Haba' is a lima bean from Dominican Republic that is highly sought after.  It grows well and is productive even in poor soils.  Ivory colored seeds with purple mottling.

en.name: Humidity Resistant
en.description: 'Humidity Resistant' is a variety of lima bean that is drought tolerant but also tolerant of high humidity. The smooth, thin beans are black in color.

en.name: 7-Year Lima
en.description: '7-Year' is a variety that originated in Central America, but has been bred in parts of East Africa and South Africa and is commonly used as a cover crop. If grown along the ground, it produces a 60 cm high mat of foliage that smothers weeds.  It can also be trellised for easier seed harvest. The seeds are large, with distinctive red caps atop the seeds.

en.name: Hopi Red
en.description: ‘Hopi Red’ are a reddish small-seeded lima bean that was originally collected from three farmers near Hotevilla on the Hopi reservation in North America.

en.name: UHDP
en.description: Sweet in flavor, this is a tall plant with long-shaped fruit.

en.name: Mash Melon
en.description: Light green, sweet flesh with many seeds.

en.name: Royal Project
en.description: Cape gooseberries look and taste like a sweet orange version of a cherry tomato. They have a paper-like sheath on the outside that should be removed before eating.

en.name: PI 538255
en.description: Yellow inflorescence, white stem.

en.name: PI 538320
en.description: Red inflorescence, white stem.

en.name: PI 606767
en.description: Light brown inflorescence.

en.name: Chiang Mai
en.description: Multicolored seeds, from white to brown to grey. Originated from plants naturalized in northern Thailand.

en.name: Chiang Dao
en.description: From North Thailand’s Chiang Dao district.

en.name: Pang Daeng
en.description: A northern Thailand grain sorghum variety mostly grown for livestock feed.

en.name: PI 521344
en.description: A sweet sorghum variety. The seeds are red in color. The plant takes about five months to produce seed.

en.name: Local Thai
en.description: From the Mae Jam and Pai regions of North Thailand. Seeds are black in color. Can be made into a sweetener.

en.name: Naga Popcorn
en.description: From Northeast India. Small ears with hard, round, yellow kernels. Can be fed to animals. Hardy crop.

en.name: Naga Multi-Colored
en.description: From Northeast India. Mid-sized ears with multi-colored kernels. Grows vigorously under suitable conditions

en.name: Wachichu
en.description: Ranges from orange, light purple, to white. Heirloom variety from USA.

en.name: Samoeng Purple
en.description: Grains are a dark purple color.

en.name: Chiang Dao
en.description: Similar to Lampang variety. White color.

en.name: Lampang
en.description: White-seeded variety with some slightly-purple kernels.

en.name: Dark Red
en.description: Wine red seeds with 19 cm pods. Grows vigorously.

en.name: Orange
en.description: Multi-colored orange and yellow. Full shape. Used for fodder.

en.name: Light Yellow
en.description: Tall plant with slender, light yellow ears. Used for fodder.

en.name: Dark Purple
en.description: Sticky and sweet kernels. 10-15cm long. Dark purple color.

en.name: Esaan Yellow
en.description: Similar to Hawaiian Supersweet #9. 111 days to harvest.

en.name: Burmese
en.description: A tall, well-branched plant. Bluishgreen in color and disease-resistant.

en.name: Pyin Oo Lwin
en.description: Seeds, leaves, and roots are all edible.

en.name: Tung Kwang Tong
en.description: Local Thai annual, semi-hardy, up to 1-2 m (3-6 ft) tall with bright orange or yellow flowers.

en.name: Local Thai
en.description: Strong variety from northern Thailand. Easy to grow, with potent flavor.

en.name: Burmese
en.description: A short, hardy variety from Burma about 0.5 m tall.

en.name: Sweet Local Thai
en.description: Dark green leaves with purple flowers and soft leaves. Used in both Thai traditional medicine and in food for flavoring, sweet basil is an annual herb. Its leaves are used as a spice. In medicinal applications, sweet basil is used to help headaches, coughs, diarrhea, and constipation.

en.name: Local Thai
en.description: Small leaves, blue/green in color.

en.name: Local Thai
en.description: From the Fang District of northern Thailand. Green in color (rather than the more common purple variety) and easy to grow. ECHO Asia uses it in an integrated pest management system.

en.name: Africa Heirloom
en.description: Prolific bloomer with large yellow and orange double flowers on vigorous bushy plants.

en.name: Nematicidal Heirloom
en.description: Small white flowers. Plant is leggy but serves as a hearty variety effective against nematodes. Heirloom variety from USA.

en.name: Red Marietta
en.description: Red flowers with yellow-edged petals. Continuous succession of beautiful 2” blooms provides a spectacular splash of color all summer and into fall! Perfect for borders or scattered throughout the garden. Classic marigold aroma.

en.name: Local Thai
en.description: Plants can reach up to 6 feet (1.8 m) tall and 2 feet (0.6 m) wide in just a few months. Good for companion planting.

en.name: Thung Kwang Tong
en.description: Thai variety with a mix of purple and white flowers.

en.name: UHDP
en.description: A local variety promoted for its ability to prevent soil erosion in sloping agriculture systems.

en.name: Philippines
en.description: Medium-sized nitrogen-fixing tree. Can attain heights of 3-5 m (10-16 ft) within two years.

en.name: UHDP
en.description: Reddish brown pods (when mature),from the UHDP Center in Northern Thailand. Red leucaena has been promoted by the Mindanao Baptist Rural Life Center for its tolerance of acidic soil and as a psyllid resistant alternative to L. leucocephala.

en.name: K-500 Cunningham
en.description: An excellent forage variety developed in Australia. A cross-breed between Salvador and Peru-type cultivars.

en.name: Burma
en.description: The leaves are high in protein and can be used as fodder for pigs and cattle. Can be planted to provide ground cover and erosion control between perennial crops. Suitable for rehabilitating degraded land.

en.name: Local Thai
en.description: Local variety from Thailand. Fast-growing, strong wood producer, does not fix nitrogen.

en.name: Local Thai Mix
en.description: White flower type from Thailand.

en.name: Burmese
en.description: Drought tolerant once established and ready for harvest approximately three months after planting.

en.name: Chiang Dao
en.description: A local variety that averages 2.5 m (8.2 ft) in height. The flowers are around 15 cm (6 in) across and petals are yellow in color. The seeds have a striped pattern and the kernel is quite tasty.

en.name: Black Seed
en.description: Local northern Thai variety with kernels black in color. Can grow between 2-3 m (6.5-10 ft) in height.

en.name: Lao
en.description: Fruits are 3 to 5 cm ( 1.2-2 in) in diameter with 4 to 5 points. Green pods ripen to blackish brown.

en.name: Lao
en.description: Small white seed and small fruit. Caution required when harvesting, as pod tends to split open and release seeds.

en.name: Kasetsart
en.description: Big white seed and fruit, resistant to disease. Pod does not split before harvest.

en.name: AVRDC Black
en.description: Taller fruit and darker green pod than Lao variety with high yield. Black seed.

en.name: Thailand Mix
en.description: Local Thai variety with good flavor.

en.name: Pa-O Small
en.description: From Shan State, Myanmar. Leaves, pods, and seeds are edible.

en.name: Chiang Dao
en.description: Local Thai variety with a bushy growth habit. Matures in 120 days.

en.name: ECHO Asia
en.description: A more aggressive climber than the local Thai variety.

en.name: Mae Jo
en.description: Thai variety with large, pink seed. Matures in about 180 days.

en.name: Burma Red
en.description: Produces small, rough-coated, red-brown seed (Desi type); approximately 3.5 months to first seed harvest.

en.name: Burma Round
en.description: Produces large, round, smooth, light brown seed (Kabuli type); approximately 4.5 months to first harvest.

en.name: Chiang Mai
en.description: A prolific local variety. Can grow up to 2 m (6 ft).

en.name: GMCC
en.description: Buckwheat, a short-season crop, does well on low-fertility or acidic soils, but the soil must be well-drained.

en.name: Lao
en.description: This variety has a light yellow flower.

en.name: Local Thai
en.description: From Ban Chan region of northern Thailand. Produces well with small seeds.

en.name: Chiang Dao Mix
en.description: A white-seeded field lablab.

en.name: Highworth
en.description: Produces nonshattering pods with black seeds. Quick maturing; yields well.

en.name: Burmese
en.description: Easy to grow variety from Myanmar. Bushy and good producer of seed with potential as a cover crop.

en.name: Chiang Dao
en.description: Climbing variety. Requires short days for flower and pod production. Seeds are black.

en.name: Bush
en.description: Doesn’t climb. Seeds are white with black

en.name: Bhutanese Bush
en.description: Bush characteristics. Does not need a trellis.

en.name: Mae Ai
en.description: Pole variety, the pod is a distinctive speckled-pink color. Shows good resistance to disease. Considered to have a creamy / nutty flavor.

en.name: Ubon
en.description: Bush characteristics. Does not need a trellis.

en.name: Palawan
en.description: From Palawan, Philippines. Bushy with a red seed and green pod. Good production and somewhat resistant to pests and disease.

en.name: Burmese Green
en.description: Day-neutral, bush variety. Green seed.

en.name: Lao
en.description: Day-neutral, bush variety; approximately 60 days from seed to flowering. Green seed.

en.name: Lombok
en.description: Indonesian variety. Taller than other varieties - will grow to about 1 m (3.2 ft). The pods are larger and will produce more seed.

en.name: Thai Green
en.description: Light yellow-green seed, slightly larger than ‘ECHO’ variety.

en.name: ECHO
en.description: Light yellow-green seed.

en.name: Thai Department of Agriculture
en.description: Local Thai variety; black seed.

en.name: Chiang Dao
en.description: Local Thai variety, red seed.

en.name: Chiang Dao
en.description: Vining cowpea, good GMCC. Vines less than 1 m long; pods approximately 20 cm (8 in) long.

en.name: India Black Eyed Pea
en.description: Trellising vine. Prolific seed-bearing variety. Beans are white with black spot around hilum.

en.name: Pa-O
en.description: Speckled dark brown and white seed. Vining-type with a bumpy pod. From Shan State, Myanmar.

en.name: Lahu / Mae Ai
en.description: Bush variety; shows good resistance to disease; grayish seed.

en.name: Samoeng
en.description: Short creeping vine; intercropped with upland rice; tasty plump pod; black seed.

en.name: Red Maroon
en.description: Produces dark red pods that can reach 20 cm (7.8 in)but are eaten when 12-15 cm (4.7-6 in) long.

en.name: Star of David
en.description: The plant is not covered with hairs. They are much less slimy than other types of okra.

en.name: Clemson Spineless
en.description: Prolific producer of dark green, spineless pods

en.name: Bhutanese
en.description: Produces green pods, eaten when 7-10 cm (3-5 in) long. Pods become hairy and spiny when mature, but young pods are edible.

en.name: Manee Maejo
en.description: This variety has two colors, green and light maroon. The pod of this variety is loger than the Red maroon variety

en.name: AVRDC
en.description: Smaller-leafed than Bangadesh variety and vigorous.Leaves and tender stems are eaten as salad, boiled, stewed or stir-fried, or in soups.

en.name: Arunothai
en.description: Round variety about 15 cm (6 in) across.

en.name: Upland Mix
en.description: Produces a large, green edible gourd about 46-61 cm (1.5 to 2 ft) long.

en.name: ECHO
en.description: ECHO Florida variety that grows well in Southeast Asia. Leaves have a blue-green color, and plant grows to about 1.5 meters in height.

en.name: Khasi
en.description: Extremely spicy/hot variety from NE India with rounded, spiny leaves.  Performs better than other varieties if planted during rainy season.

en.name: Mae Tha
en.description: White flowers. Grows up to 48 cm (19 in) high. Heat resistant and will grow through the winter in most areas.

en.name: Extra Dwarf Pak Choi
en.description:
It has dark green, wrinkled leaves with thick, white petioles. Very tender and delicious.

This tiny pak choy is picked when just 6 cm (2.4 in) tall.The perfect baby vegetable for marketing, planting-to-harvest time is around 5-6 weeks. Can be used whole to make amazing salads and stir-fries.

en.name: Mae Tha
en.description: Productive, large-leaf variety from Green Net in Mae Tha, Thailand.

en.name: Burmese
en.description: Smaller leaves. From the Irrawaddy Delta region of Myanmar.

en.name: Huay Wai
en.description: Leaves are unique green/purple in color with serrated edges. A distinct peppery taste.

en.name: Mae Ai
en.description: Especially hot in flavor. Used for making natural pesticides.

en.name: Hawaiian
en.description: Milder peppers. 4-6 cm (1.6-2.4 in) in length.

en.name: Karen
en.description: Hot red peppers. 2-4 cm (0.8-1.6 in) in length.

en.name: Tiny Hot
en.description: Very hot, very small peppers. 2-3 (0.8-1.2 in) cm in length.

en.name: Esaan
en.description: Long fruit in 7.62 cm (3 in) pods. Extremely high yield; vigorous.

en.name: Burmese Purple
en.description: Hot peppers, deep purple to magenta and red in color. 2 - 4 cm (0.8-1.6 in) in length.

en.name: Mae Ai Cream
en.description: Hot peppers, white in color. 2 - 4 cm (0.8 - 1.6 in) in length.

en.name: Thung Kwang Tong
en.description: Edible leaves, strong smell, good for companion planting.

en.name: Chiang Mai Mix
en.description: White and blue flowers. Used for drinks and making salad.

en.name: Local Thai
en.description: Variety from a local northern Thai community. Very easy to grow and eat.

en.name: Burmese
en.description: Small variety about 6 cm (2.3 in) in length and round in shape. Good for pickling or fermenting.

en.name: Khmer

en.name: Mae Tha
en.description: Good pickling variety. Approximately 30 days from seed to flowering. Large fruit .averaging 30 x 7 cm (12 x 2.75 in) in size

en.name: Uberlandia

en.name: Bhutanese

en.name: Green Bowl MJ3
en.description: Leaves are green in color with wavy edges.

en.name: Red Oak

en.name: Chiang Mai

en.name: Local Thai

en.name: Chiang Dao

en.name: Red Bowl MJ4

en.name: Celtuce

en.name: Burmese

en.description: Similar to Tung Kwang Tong variety
